Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, and security products are applied within one month of release.

Title: Apply critical internet-facing OS patches within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of internet-facing servers and internet-facing network devices are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title: Apply non-critical internet-facing OS patches within two weeks
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of internet-facing servers and internet-facing network devices are applied within two weeks of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title: Apply OS patches for workstations and non-internet servers/network devices within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, non-internet-facing servers and non-internet-facing network devices are applied within one month of release.

Title: Apply critical OS patches for workstations and non-internet-facing servers/network devices within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, non-internet-facing servers and non-internet-facing network devices are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title: Apply non-critical OS patches for workstations and non-internet servers/network devices within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of workstations, non-internet-facing servers and non-internet-facing network devices are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title: Apply critical OS patches for other IT equipment within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of IT equipment other than workstations, servers and network devices are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title: Apply non-critical OS patches for other IT equipment within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in operating systems of IT equipment other than workstations, servers and network devices are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title: Apply critical driver patches within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in drivers are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title: Apply non-critical driver patches within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in drivers are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title: Apply critical firmware patches within 48 hours
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in firmware are applied within 48 hours of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as critical by vendors or when working exploits exist.

Title: Apply non-critical firmware patches within one month
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in firmware are applied within one month of release when vulnerabilities are assessed as non-critical by vendors and no working exploits exist.

Title: High-assurance IT patches only with ASD approval per methods/timeframes
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: Patches, updates or other vendor mitigations for vulnerabilities in high assurance IT equipment are applied only when approved by ASD, and in doing so, using methods and timeframes prescribed by ASD.

Title: Remove unsupported online services
Description from ISM: Online services that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

Title: Remove unsupported office/browser/email/pdf/security products and Adobe Flash Player
Description from ISM: Office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, Adobe Flash Player, and security products that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

Title: Remove other unsupported applications
Description from ISM: Applications other than office productivity suites, web browsers and their extensions, email clients, PDF applications, Adobe Flash Player, and security products that are no longer supported by vendors are removed.

Title: Replace unsupported operating systems
Description from ISM: Operating systems that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

Title: Replace unsupported internet-facing network devices
Description from ISM: Internet-facing network devices that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

Title: Replace unsupported non-internet network devices
Description from ISM: Non-internet-facing network devices that are no longer supported by vendors are replaced.

Title: Replace unsupported networked IT equipment
Description from ISM: Networked IT equipment that is no longer supported by vendors is replaced.

Title: Implement compensating controls until removal/replacement possible
Description from ISM: When applications, operating systems, network devices or networked IT equipment that are no longer supported by vendors cannot be immediately removed or replaced, compensating controls are implemented until such time that they can be removed or replaced.

Title: Digital preservation policy maintained
Description from ISM: A digital preservation policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Data backup processes and procedures maintained
Description from ISM: Data backup processes, and supporting data backup procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Data restoration processes and procedures maintained
Description from ISM: Data restoration processes, and supporting data restoration procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Backups performed and retained per business criticality
Description from ISM: Backups of data, applications and settings are performed and retained in accordance with business criticality and business continuity requirements.

Title: Synchronise backups to common point in time
Description from ISM: Backups of data, applications and settings are synchronised to enable restoration to a common point in time.

Title: Store backups securely and resiliently
Description from ISM: Backups of data, applications and settings are retained in a secure and resilient manner.

Title: Prevent unprivileged users accessing others' backups
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts cannot access backups belonging to other user accounts.

Title: Prevent unprivileged users accessing own backups
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts cannot access their own backups.

Title: Privileged users (except backup admins) cannot access others' backups
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts (excluding backup administrator accounts) cannot access backups belonging to other user accounts.

Title: Privileged users (except backup admins) cannot access own backups
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts (excluding backup administrator accounts) cannot access their own backups.

Title: Prevent unprivileged users modifying/deleting backups
Description from ISM: Unprivileged user accounts are prevented from modifying and deleting backups.

Title: Prevent privileged users (except backup admins) modifying/deleting backups
Description from ISM: Privileged user accounts (excluding backup administrator accounts) are prevented from modifying and deleting backups.

Title: Backup admins prevented from modifying/deleting backups during retention period
Description from ISM: Backup administrator accounts are prevented from modifying and deleting backups during their retention period.

Title: Test restoration to common point in time in disaster recovery exercises
Description from ISM: Restoration of data, applications and settings from backups to a common point in time is tested as part of disaster recovery exercises.

Title: Event logging policy maintained
Description from ISM: An event logging policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Centralised event logging facility implemented
Description from ISM: A centralised event logging facility is implemented.

Title: Send event logs to centralised logging facility as soon as possible
Description from ISM: Event logs sent to a centralised event logging facility are done so as soon as possible after they occur.

Title: Encrypt event logs in transit
Description from ISM: Event logs sent to a centralised event logging facility are encrypted in transit.

Title: Protect event logs from unauthorised access
Description from ISM: Event logs are protected from unauthorised access.

Title: Protect logs from unauthorised modification/deletion
Description from ISM: Event logs are protected from unauthorised modification and deletion.

Title: Use accurate & consistent time source for logging
Description from ISM: An accurate and consistent time source is used for event logging.

Title: Capture date/time/user/process/filename/event/equipment for event logs
Description from ISM: For each event logged, the date and time of the event, the relevant user or process, the relevant filename, the event description, and the information technology equipment involved are captured.

Title: Capture and store event logs in consistent-structured format where possible
Description from ISM: To the extent possible, event logs are captured and stored in a consistent and structured format.

Title: Analyse critical server event logs promptly to detect events
Description from ISM: Event logs from critical servers are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse internet-facing server event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from internet-facing servers are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse non-internet-facing server event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from non-internet-facing servers are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse workstation event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from workstations are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse security product event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from security products are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse internet-facing network device event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from internet-facing network devices are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse non-internet-facing network device event logs promptly
Description from ISM: Event logs from non-internet-facing network devices are analysed in a timely manner to detect cyber security events.

Title: Analyse security events to identify incidents promptly
Description from ISM: Cyber security events are analysed in a timely manner to identify cyber security incidents.

Title: Retain event logs in searchable manner for >=12 months
Description from ISM: Event logs are retained in a searchable manner for at least 12 months.

Title: Retain event logs as per NAA AFDA Express v2 retention rules
Description from ISM: Event logs are retained as per minimum retention requirements for various classes of records as set out by the National Archives of Australia’s Administrative Functions Disposal Authority Express (AFDA Express) Version 2 publication.

Title: Segregate dev/test/staging/prod environments
Description from ISM: Development, testing, staging and production environments are segregated.

Title: Development only takes place in development environments
Description from ISM: Development and modification of software only takes place in development environments.

Title: Do not use production data in non-prod unless equally secured
Description from ISM: Data from production environments is not used in non-production environments unless the non-production environment is secured to at least the same level as the production environment.

Title: Maintain authoritative source for software
Description from ISM: An authoritative source for software is established and maintained.

Title: Use authoritative software source for all development activities
Description from ISM: The authoritative source for software is used for all software development activities.

Title: Prevent unauthorised access to authoritative source
Description from ISM: Unauthorised access to the authoritative source for software is prevented.

Title: Prevent unauthorised modification of authoritative source
Description from ISM: Unauthorised modification of the authoritative source for software is prevented.

Title: Use issue tracking solution to link development tasks to security decisions
Description from ISM: An issue tracking solution is used to link software development tasks to security issues and decisions, change or feature requests, programming issues, or bug fixes.

Title: Scan all software artefacts for malicious code before import
Description from ISM: All software artefacts are scanned for malicious code before being imported into the authoritative source for software, including all compiled code, third-party libraries and software components.

Title: Verify artefacts by signature or secure hash before import
Description from ISM: All software artefacts are verified by a digital signature, or a secure hash provided over a secure channel, before being imported into the authoritative source for software.

Title: Test third-party artefacts with SAST/DAST/SCA before import and periodically throughout SDLC
Description from ISM: All imported or referenced third-party software artefacts are tested using static application security testing (SAST), dynamic application security testing (DAST) and software composition analysis (SCA) before being imported into the authoritative source for software and periodically throughout the software development life cycle.

Title: Restrict third-party artefact imports to trustworthy sources
Description from ISM: The authoritative source for software restricts the use and import of third-party libraries and software components to trustworthy sources.

Title: Scan commits to block secrets from being stored in authoritative source
Description from ISM: Scanning is used during commits to identify plain text or encoded secrets and keys, which are then blocked from being stored in the authoritative source for software.

Title: Use compilers/build tools with security features
Description from ISM: Compilers, interpreters and build tools (including pipelines) that provide security features to improve executable file security are implemented and such security features are used.

Title: Ensure automated tests complete cleanly before builds
Description from ISM: The build solution ensures that all automated testing is completed without warnings, alerts or errors before building software artefacts.

Title: Document and maintain software security requirements
Description from ISM: All software security requirements are documented, stored securely and maintained throughout the software development life cycle.

Title: Document security design decisions during development
Description from ISM: Security design decisions are documented and reviewed throughout the software development cycle.

Title: Identify security roles/responsibilities/knowledge needs for SDLC
Description from ISM: Security roles, responsibilities and knowledge requirements required to support the software development life cycle are identified and documented.

Title: Document security responsibilities for developers
Description from ISM: Security responsibilities for software developers are identified and documented.

Title: Train developers lacking sufficient cyber security skills
Description from ISM: Software developers that lack sufficient cyber security knowledge and skills required for their projects or tasks undertake suitable training on secure software development and programming practices.

Title: Maintain developer cyber security knowledge/skills register
Description from ISM: A software developer cyber security knowledge and skills register is implemented and maintained.

Title: Follow Secure by Design principles in SDLC
Description from ISM: Secure by Design principles and practices are followed throughout the software development life cycle.

Title: Use threat modelling in support of SDLC
Description from ISM: Threat modelling is used in support of the software development life cycle.

Title: Review threat model throughout SDLC
Description from ISM: The software threat model is reviewed throughout the software development life cycle to ensure it reflects the as-built software and any changes to the threat environment.

Title: Use secure programming practices for chosen language
Description from ISM: Secure programming practices for the chosen programming language are used for software development.

Title: Use memory-safe languages or safer practices
Description from ISM: Memory-safe programming languages, or less preferably memory-safe programming practices, are used for software development.

Title: Follow Secure by Default principles in SDLC
Description from ISM: Secure by Default principles and practices are followed throughout the software development life cycle, including by ensuring that all built-in security measures are included and enabled in the base product at no extra cost to consumers.

Title: Use SecDevOps practices
Description from ISM: SecDevOps practices are used for software development.

Title: Architect software for readability & maintainability
Description from ISM: Software is architected and structured to support readability and maintainability.

Title: Digitally sign executables in development
Description from ISM: Files containing executable content are digitally signed by a certificate with a verifiable chain of trust as part of software development.

Title: Digitally sign installers/patches or provide checksums
Description from ISM: Installers, patches and updates are digitally signed or provided with cryptographic checksums as part of software development.

Title: Software has no default credentials or created on first install by installing organisation
Description from ISM: Software has no default credentials; however, if credentials are required, they are created on first install by the installing organisation.

Title: Backwards compatibility must not weaken security
Description from ISM: Application backwards compatibility does not compromise any security measures or features.

Title: Software prevents logging sensitive data during user impersonation
Description from ISM: Where software allows user impersonation, sensitive data is not logged and appropriate permissions are set.

Title: Notify users via secondary channel when authentication factor is reset
Description from ISM: Where software allows an authentication factor to be reset, the user is notified of the reset through a secondary channel.

Title: Prevent non-admins altering their roles
Description from ISM: Where software supports multiple user roles, non-administrative users are prevented from altering their profile permissions or privileges.

Title: Force re-authentication when permissions/credentials change
Description from ISM: When user permissions or credentials are changed, software forces all impacted users to re-authenticate.

Title: Validate digital signatures against trust chain & revocation list or OSCP
Description from ISM: When digital signatures are processed by software, they are validated against a certificate trust chain and checked for revocation using a Certificate Revocation List or with the Online Certificate Status Protocol.

Title: Software generates logs to support detection of security events
Description from ISM: Software generates sufficient event logs to support the detection of cyber security events.

Title: Event logs produced by software protect sensitive data
Description from ISM: Event logs produced by software ensure that any sensitive data is protected.

Title: Provide secure configuration guidance to consumers
Description from ISM: Secure configuration guidance, in the form of a hardening guide or loosening guide, is produced and made available to consumers as part of software development.

Title: Provide software end-of-life procedures to consumers
Description from ISM: End of life procedures for software, covering how to remove the software and how to archive or destroy any user accounts and data, are produced and made available to consumers.

Title: Use SBOM when available for third-party components during software development
Description from ISM: If a software bill of materials is available for imported third-party software components, it is used during software development to ensure such software components have no known vulnerabilities.

Title: Produce SBOM to consumers of software
Description from ISM: A software bill of materials is produced and made available to consumers of software.

Title: Use CBOM when available for 3rd-party components during development
Description from ISM: If a cryptographic bill of materials is available for imported third-party software components, it is used during software development to ensure such software components provide support for standardised implementations of ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms.

Title: Produce CBOM for consumers of software
Description from ISM: A cryptographic bill of materials is produced and made available to consumers of software.

Title: Use build provenance for third-party components when available during development
Description from ISM: If a software build provenance is available for imported third-party software components, it is used during software development to ensure such software components are built to an appropriate standard.

Title: Produce software build provenance for consumers
Description from ISM: A software build provenance is produced and made available to consumers of software.

Title: Authenticate & authorise clients for internet accessible APIs
Description from ISM: Authentication and authorisation of clients is performed when clients call network APIs that facilitate modification of data and are accessible over the internet.

Title: Authenticate & authorise clients for non-internet accessible APIs
Description from ISM: Authentication and authorisation of clients is performed when clients call network APIs that facilitate modification of data but are not accessible over the internet.

Title: Authenticate & authorise clients for internet accessible APIs accessing non-public data
Description from ISM: Authentication and authorisation of clients is performed when clients call network APIs that facilitate access to data not authorised for release into the public domain and are accessible over the internet.

Title: Authenticate & authorise clients for non-internet accessible APIs accessing non-public data
Description from ISM: Authentication and authorisation of clients is performed when clients call network APIs that facilitate access to data not authorised for release into the public domain but are not accessible over the internet.

Title: Internet accessible APIs that modify/access non-public data are centrally logged
Description from ISM: Network API calls that facilitate modification of data, or access to data not authorised for release into the public domain, and are accessible over the internet, are centrally logged.

Title: Non-internet accessible APIs that modify/access non-public data are centrally logged
Description from ISM: Network API calls that facilitate modification of data, or access to data not authorised for release into the public domain, but are not accessible over the internet, are centrally logged.

Title: Validate & sanitise all internet input received by software
Description from ISM: Validation and sanitisation are performed on all input received over the internet by software.

Title: Validate & sanitise all local network input received by software
Description from ISM: Validation and sanitisation are performed on all input received over a local network by software.

Title: Document & test all input validation rules with positive/negative tests
Description from ISM: All input validation rules are documented, matched in code and tested with both positive and negative unit testing or integration testing.

Title: Validate data sources & serialised inputs before deserialisation
Description from ISM: Data sources and serialised data inputs are validated before being deserialised.

Title: Restrict file uploads to specific types & scan malicious content pre-access
Description from ISM: File uploads or input are restricted to specific file types, with malicious content scanning occurring prior to file access, file execution or file storage.

Title: Filter database queries for legitimate content/syntax
Description from ISM: All queries to databases from software are filtered for legitimate content and correct syntax.

Title: Use parameterised queries/stored procedures for DB interactions
Description from ISM: Parameterised queries or stored procedures, instead of dynamically generated queries, are used by software for database interactions.

Title: Limit error info to avoid DB structure disclosure
Description from ISM: Software is designed or configured to provide as little error information as possible about the structure of databases.

Title: Log user-initiated DB queries & resulting crash/error messages centrally
Description from ISM: All queries to databases from software that are initiated by users, and any resulting crash or error messages, are centrally logged.

Title: Comprehensively test software with SAST/DAST/SCA before release & periodically
Description from ISM: Software is comprehensively tested for vulnerabilities, using SAST, DAST and SCA prior to its initial release, any subsequent releases and periodically in order to attempt to identify any previously unidentified vulnerabilities.

Title: Use code reviews to ensure Secure by Design principles/practices
Description from ISM: Code reviews are utilised to ensure software meets Secure by Design principles and practices as well as secure programming practices.

Title: Conduct security-focused peer reviews on critical/security-focused components
Description from ISM: Software developer-supported security-focused peer reviews are conducted on all critical and security-focused software components.

Title: Use unit/integration tests covering positive/negative cases
Description from ISM: Unit testing and integration testing, covering both positive and negative use cases, are used to ensure code quality and security.

Title: Implement vulnerability disclosure program
Description from ISM: A vulnerability disclosure program is implemented to assist with the secure development and maintenance of products and services.

Title: Vulnerability disclosure policy maintained
Description from ISM: A vulnerability disclosure policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Vulnerability disclosure processes & procedures maintained
Description from ISM: Vulnerability disclosure processes, and supporting vulnerability disclosure procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Host security.txt for each internet-facing domain
Description from ISM: A ‘security.txt’ file is hosted for each of an organisation’s internet-facing website domains to assist in the responsible disclosure of vulnerabilities in the organisation’s products and services.

Title: Publicly disclose vulnerabilities responsibly with CWE/CPE
Description from ISM: Vulnerabilities identified in software are publicly disclosed in a responsible and timely manner, including with Common Weakness Enumeration and Common Platform Enumeration information.

Title: Resolve software vulnerabilities promptly
Description from ISM: Vulnerabilities identified in software are resolved in a timely manner.

Title: Perform root cause analysis and remediate entire vulnerability classes
Description from ISM: In resolving vulnerabilities, root cause analysis is performed and, to the greatest extent possible, entire vulnerability classes are remediated.

Title: Log security-relevant usage/errors/crashes centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant usage, error messages and crashes for software are centrally logged.

Title: AI documentation (including model & system cards) maintained
Description from ISM: Artificial intelligence-specific documentation, including model and system cards (or equivalent artefacts), is used to document model characteristics, system architectures, use cases and security risks.

Title: Store AI models in non-executable format
Description from ISM: Artificial intelligence models are stored in a non-executable file format that does not allow arbitrary code execution.

Title: Prevent exposure of exact AI confidence scores
Description from ISM: The exposure of exact artificial intelligence model confidence scores in API responses or user interfaces is prevented.

Title: Verify source & integrity of AI models
Description from ISM: The source and integrity of artificial intelligence models, structures and weights are verified.

Title: Verify source & integrity of AI training data
Description from ISM: The source and integrity of training data for artificial intelligence models is verified.

Title: Use data validation and verification techniques to ensure AI training data reliability
Description from ISM: Data validation and verification techniques are used to ensure the reliability and accuracy of training data used by artificial intelligence models.

Title: Monitor AI model performance & investigate anomalies
Description from ISM: Artificial intelligence model performance metrics are monitored and anomalies are investigated.

Title: Apply rate limiting to AI inference queries
Description from ISM: Rate limiting is applied to inference queries for artificial intelligence models.

Title: Enforce resource limits for AI models
Description from ISM: Resource limits are enforced for artificial intelligence models.

Title: Implement fine-grained access control for AI apps
Description from ISM: Access control policies are implemented to enforce fine-grained permissions for artificial intelligence applications.

Title: Use role-based access control for AI apps
Description from ISM: Role-based access controls are implemented for artificial intelligence applications to restrict access to sensitive data.

Title: Generative AI evaluates prompts to detect adversarial inputs
Description from ISM: Generative artificial intelligence applications evaluate user prompts to detect and mitigate adversarial inputs or suffixes designed to elicit unintended behaviour or assist in the generation of sensitive or harmful content.

Title: Implement content filtering to prevent sensitive/harmful AI output
Description from ISM: Content filtering is implemented by artificial intelligence applications to detect and block sensitive data exposure and improper output.

Title: Use OWASP MASVS for mobile app development
Description from ISM: The OWASP Mobile Application Security Verification Standard is used in the development of mobile applications.

Title: Use robust web frameworks for web apps
Description from ISM: Robust web application frameworks are used in the development of web applications.

Title: Use OWASP ASVS for web app development
Description from ISM: The OWASP Application Security Verification Standard is used in the development of web applications.

Title: Use OWASP Proactive Controls in web app development
Description from ISM: The OWASP Top 10 Proactive Controls are used in the development of web applications.

Title: Mitigate OWASP Top 10 in web app development
Description from ISM: The OWASP Top 10 are mitigated in the development of web applications.

Title: Set secure cookie flags by default if supported
Description from ISM: If supported, web application session cookies set the HttpOnly flag, Secure flag and the SameSite flag by default.

Title: Use opaque signed tokens in session cookies
Description from ISM: Web application session cookies contain only digitally signed opaque bearer tokens.

Title: Use non-sequential random high-entropy IDs if opaque tokens not signed
Description from ISM: Web application session cookies using opaque bearer tokens that are not digitally signed use non-sequential random identifiers with a minimum of 128 bits of entropy, preferably 256 bits of entropy.

Title: Manage web sessions centrally server-side
Description from ISM: Web application sessions are centrally managed server side.

Title: Support Single Sign On and Single Logout equally
Description from ISM: Web applications that support Single Sign On equally support Single Logout.

Title: Specify CSP, HSTS and X-Frame-Options in response headers
Description from ISM: Content-Security-Policy, Hypertext Transfer Protocol Strict Transport Security and X-Frame-Options are specified by web server software via security policy in response headers.

Title: Offer all web content exclusively over HTTPS
Description from ISM: All web application content is offered exclusively using HTTPS.

Title: Mitigate OWASP Security Top 10 for web APIs
Description from ISM: The OWASP API Security Top 10 are mitigated in the development of web APIs.

Title: Perform output encoding for web app output
Description from ISM: Output encoding is performed on all output produced by web applications.

Title: Functionally separate database and web servers
Description from ISM: Database servers and web servers are functionally separated.

Title: Encrypt communications between DB and web servers
Description from ISM: Data communicated between database servers and web servers is encrypted.

Title: Place DB servers on separate network segment from workstations
Description from ISM: Database servers are placed on a different network segment to user workstations.

Title: Use network access controls to restrict DB communications
Description from ISM: Network access controls are implemented to restrict database server communications to strictly defined network resources that require access to the database server.

Title: Disable DB networking if only local access required
Description from ISM: If only local access to a database is required, networking functionality of database management system applications are disabled or directed to listen solely to the localhost interface.

Title: Segregate DB servers across environments
Description from ISM: Database servers for development, testing, staging and production environments are segregated.

Title: Database register maintained
Description from ISM: A database register is developed, implemented, maintained and verified on a regular basis.

Title: Apply file-based access controls to DB files
Description from ISM: File-based access controls are applied to database files.

Title: Classify DBs by contained data sensitivity
Description from ISM: Databases and their contents are classified based on the sensitivity or classification of data that they contain.

Title: Restrict DB user access based on duties
Description from ISM: Database users’ ability to access, insert, modify and remove database contents is restricted based on their work duties.

Title: Enforce need-to-know principle via least privilege and tokenisation
Description from ISM: The need-to-know principle is enforced for database contents through the application of minimum privileges, database views, database roles and data tokenisation.

Title: Do not use production DB content in non-production environment unless secured equally
Description from ISM: Database contents from production environments are not used in non-production environments unless the non-production environment is secured to at least the same level as the production environment.

Title: Log security-relevant DB events centrally
Description from ISM:
Security-relevant events for databases are centrally logged, including:
• access or modification of particularly important content
• addition of new users, especially privileged users
• changes to user roles or privileges
• attempts to elevate user privileges
• queries containing comments
• queries containing multiple embedded queries
• database and query alerts or failures
• database structure changes
• database administrator actions
• use of executable commands
• database logons and logoffs.

Title: Email usage policy maintained
Description from ISM: An email usage policy is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Block access to non-approved webmail
Description from ISM: Access to non-approved webmail services is blocked.

Title: Apply protective markings as per highest sensitivity to emails
Description from ISM: Protective markings are applied to emails and reflect the highest sensitivity or classification of the subject, body and attachments.

Title: Protective marking tools do not auto-insert markings
Description from ISM: Protective marking tools do not automatically insert protective markings into emails.

Title: Protective marking tools restrict markings to authorised levels
Description from ISM: Protective marking tools do not allow users to select protective markings that a system has not been authorised to process, store or communicate.

Title: Protective marking tools prevent downgrading markings on reply/forward
Description from ISM: Protective marking tools do not allow users replying to or forwarding emails to select protective markings lower than previously used.

Title: Configure email servers to block/log/report emails with inappropriate markings
Description from ISM: Email servers are configured to block, log and report emails with inappropriate protective markings.

Title: Notify senders/recipients of blocked emails
Description from ISM: The intended recipients of blocked inbound emails, and the senders of blocked outbound emails, are notified.

Title: Do not send AUSTEO/AGAO/REL emails to distribution lists unless all recipients' nationality known
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: Emails containing Australian Eyes Only, Australian Government Access Only or Releasable To data are not sent to email distribution lists unless the nationality of all members of email distribution lists can be confirmed.

Title: Route emails via centralised gateways
Description from ISM: Emails are routed via centralised email gateways.

Title: Use authenticated & encrypted channel to route emails via centralised email gateways
Description from ISM: When users send or receive emails, an authenticated and encrypted channel is used to route emails via their organisation’s centralised email gateways.

Title: Maintain backup/alternative email gateways at same standard
Description from ISM: Where backup or alternative email gateways are in place, they are maintained at the same standard as the primary email gateway.

Title: Email servers only relay for their domains
Description from ISM: Email servers only relay emails destined for or originating from their domains (including subdomains).

Title: Enable opportunistic TLS on email servers that connect to public networks
Description from ISM: Opportunistic TLS encryption is enabled on email servers that make incoming or outgoing email connections over public network infrastructure.

Title: Enable MTA-STS to prevent unencrypted transfers between email servers
Description from ISM: MTA-STS is enabled to prevent the unencrypted transfer of emails between email servers.

Title: SPF specifies authorised email servers
Description from ISM: SPF is used to specify authorised email servers (or lack thereof) for an organisation’s domains (including subdomains).

Title: Use hard fail SPF record when specifying authorised email servers
Description from ISM: A hard fail SPF record is used when specifying authorised email servers (or lack thereof) for an organisation’s domains (including subdomains).

Title: Use SPF to verify incoming email authenticity
Description from ISM: SPF is used to verify the authenticity of incoming emails.

Title: Enable DKIM signing for outgoing emails
Description from ISM: DKIM signing is enabled on emails originating from an organisation’s domains (including subdomains).

Title: Verify DKIM on incoming emails
Description from ISM: DKIM signatures on incoming emails are verified.

Title: Ensure mailing lists don't break sender's DKIM signature validity
Description from ISM: Email distribution list applications used by external senders is configured such that it does not break the validity of the sender’s DKIM signature.

Title: Configure DMARC to reject failed checks
Description from ISM: DMARC records are configured for an organisation’s domains (including subdomains) such that emails are rejected if they do not pass DMARC checks.

Title: Reject incoming emails that fail DMARC
Description from ISM: Incoming emails are rejected if they do not pass DMARC checks.

Title: Implement email content filtering for harmful content
Description from ISM: Email content filtering is implemented to filter potentially harmful content in email bodies and attachments.

Title: Block external emails spoofing internal domains
Description from ISM: Emails arriving via an external connection where the email source address uses an internal domain, or internal subdomain, are blocked at the email gateway.

Title: Send undeliverable notices only to senders that can be verified with trusted means
Description from ISM: Notifications of undeliverable emails are only sent to senders that can be verified via SPF or other trusted means.

Title: Network documentation maintained
Description from ISM: Network documentation is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Network docs include high-level & logical diagrams
Description from ISM: Network documentation includes high-level network diagrams showing all connections into networks and logical network diagrams showing all critical servers, high-value servers, network devices and network security appliances.

Title: Network docs include device settings for critical assets
Description from ISM: Network documentation includes device settings for all critical servers, high-value servers, network devices and network security appliances.

Title: Third-party access to network docs limited to necessary details
Description from ISM: Network documentation provided to a third party, or published in public tender documentation, only contains details necessary for other parties to undertake contractual services.

Title: Segregate networks into zones by criticality
Description from ISM: Networks are segregated into multiple network zones according to the criticality of servers, services and data.

Title: Segregate organisation networks from service providers' networks
Description from ISM: An organisation’s networks are segregated from their service providers’ networks.

Title: Do not use VLANs to separate org networks from public infrastructure
Description from ISM: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between an organisation’s networks and public network infrastructure.

Title: Do not use VLANs to separate different security domains
Description from ISM: VLANs are not used to separate network traffic between networks belonging to different security domains.

Title: VLAN managed from most trusted security domain
Description from ISM: Network devices managing VLANs are administered from the most trusted security domain.

Title: Devices managing VLANs for different domains do not share trunks
Description from ISM: Network devices managing VLANs belonging to different security domains do not share VLAN trunks.

Title: Devices managing VLANs terminate VLANs for different domains on separate physical interfaces
Description from ISM: Network devices managing VLANs terminate VLANs belonging to different security domains on separate physical network interfaces.

Title: Limit internet connectivity to only required devices
Description from ISM: Internet connectivity for networked devices is strictly limited to those that require access.

Title: Do not expose networked management interfaces to internet
Description from ISM: Networked management interfaces for IT equipment are not directly exposed to the internet.

Title: Servers maintain functional separation to operate independently
Description from ISM: Servers maintain effective functional separation with other servers allowing them to operate independently.

Title: Servers minimise communications with other servers
Description from ISM: Servers minimise communications with other servers at the network and file system level.

Title: Encrypt all data over network infrastructure
Description from ISM: All data communicated over network infrastructure is encrypted.

Title: Disable IPv6 unless used
Description from ISM: IPv6 functionality is disabled in dual-stack network devices unless it is being used.

Title: Use IPv6-capable network security appliances
Description from ISM: IPv6 capable network security appliances are used on IPv6 and dual-stack networks.

Title: Disable IPv6 tunnelling unless required
Description from ISM: Unless explicitly required, IPv6 tunnelling is disabled on all network devices.

Title: Block IPv6 tunnelling at externally connected-network boundaries
Description from ISM: IPv6 tunnelling is blocked by network security appliances at externally-connected network boundaries.

Title: Configure DHCPv6 in stateful mode with central lease logging
Description from ISM: Dynamically assigned IPv6 addresses are configured with Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol version 6 in a stateful manner with lease data stored in a centralised event logging facility.

Title: Implement network access controls to block unauthorised devices
Description from ISM: Network access controls are implemented on networks to prevent the connection of unauthorised network devices and networked IT equipment.

Title: Limit network traffic flows within/between segments to business needs
Description from ISM: Network access controls are implemented to limit the flow of network traffic within and between network segments to only that required for business purposes.

Title: Prevent unauthorised access to network management traffic
Description from ISM: Security measures are implemented to prevent unauthorised access to network management traffic.

Title: Do not use SMBv1
Description from ISM: SMB version 1 is not used on networks.

Title: Do not use SNMPv1/v2
Description from ISM: SNMP version 1 and SNMP version 2 are not used on networks.

Title: Change default SNMP community strings & disable write access
Description from ISM: All default SNMP community strings on network devices are changed and write access is disabled.

Title: Deploy NIDS/NIPS at external gateways
Description from ISM: A NIDS or NIPS is deployed in gateways between an organisation’s networks and other networks they do not manage.

Title: Place NIDS/NIPS inside outermost firewall and log ruleset contraventions
Description from ISM: A NIDS or NIPS is located immediately inside the outermost firewall for gateways and configured to generate event logs and alerts for network traffic that contravenes any rule in a firewall ruleset.

Title: Block inbound connections from anonymity networks
Description from ISM: Inbound network connections from anonymity networks are blocked.

Title: Block outbound connections to anonymity networks
Description from ISM: Outbound network connections to anonymity networks are blocked.

Title: Encrypt DNS traffic where supported
Description from ISM: DNS traffic is encrypted by clients and servers wherever supported.

Title: Use protective DNS to block known malicious domains
Description from ISM: A protective DNS service is used to block access to known malicious domain names.

Title: Flash network devices with trusted firmware before first use
Description from ISM: Network devices are flashed with trusted firmware before they are used for the first time.

Title: Change/disable/remove default network device accounts/credentials
Description from ISM: Default user accounts or credentials for network devices, including for any pre-configured user accounts, are changed, disabled or removed during initial setup.

Title: Disable unused physical ports on network devices
Description from ISM: Unused physical ports on network devices are disabled.

Title: Restart network devices at least monthly
Description from ISM: Network devices are restarted on at least a monthly basis.

Title: Log security events for internet-facing network devices centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for internet-facing network devices are centrally logged.

Title: Log security events for non-internet-facing network devices centrally
Description from ISM: Security-relevant events for non-internet-facing network devices are centrally logged.

Title: Ensure wireless devices are Wi-Fi Alliance certified
Description from ISM: All wireless devices are Wi-Fi Alliance certified.

Title: Segregate public wireless from organisation networks
Description from ISM: Public wireless networks provided for general public use are segregated from all other organisation networks.

Title: Disable administrative interface on WAPs for wireless connections
Description from ISM: The administrative interface on wireless access points is disabled for wireless network connections.

Title: Harden wireless access point settings
Description from ISM: Settings for wireless access points are hardened.

Title: Change default SSIDs of WAPs
Description from ISM: Default SSIDs of wireless access points are changed.

Title: Non-public SSIDs not easily associated with organisation/location/function
Description from ISM: SSIDs of non-public wireless networks are not readily associated with an organisation, the location of their premises or the functionality of wireless networks.

Title: Do not disable SSID broadcasting
Description from ISM: SSID broadcasting is not disabled on wireless access points.

Title: Do not use MAC filtering for wireless restrictions
Description from ISM: MAC address filtering is not used to restrict which devices can connect to wireless networks.

Title: Do not use static addressing for wireless IP assignments
Description from ISM: Static addressing is not used for assigning IP addresses on wireless networks.

Title: Use WPA3-Enterprise 192-bit mode for wireless network traffic
Description from ISM: WPA3-Enterprise 192-bit mode is used to protect the confidentiality and integrity of all wireless network traffic.

Title: Use 802.1X EAP-TLS with X.509 certificates, disable other EAP methods
Description from ISM: 802.1X authentication with EAP-TLS, using X.509 certificates, is used for mutual authentication; with all other EAP methods disabled on supplicants and authentication servers.

Title: Use user identity confidentiality if available with EAP-TLS implementations
Description from ISM: User identity confidentiality is used if available with EAP-TLS implementations.

Title: Use evaluated supplicants/authenticators/WAPs/authentication servers
Description from ISM: Evaluated supplicants, authenticators, wireless access points and authentication servers are used in wireless networks.

Title: Generate certificates using evaluated CA or HSM
Description from ISM: Certificates are generated using an evaluated certificate authority or hardware security module.

Title: Require certificates for devices/users accessing wireless networks
Description from ISM: Certificates are required for devices and users accessing wireless networks.

Title: Protect certificates with logical/physical access controls, encryption, and user authentication
Description from ISM: Certificates are protected by logical and physical access controls, encryption, and user authentication.

Title: Set PMK caching period <= 1440 minutes (24h)
Description from ISM: The PMK caching period is not set to greater than 1440 minutes (24 hours).

Title: Disable 802.11r unless authenticator communication uses an ASD-approved cryptographic protocol
Description from ISM: The use of FT (802.11r) is disabled unless authenticator-to-authenticator communications are secured by an ASD-Approved Cryptographic Protocol.

Title: Encrypt communications between authenticators and RADIUS servers (RADIUS over IPsec/TLS)
Description from ISM: Communications between authenticators and a RADIUS server are encapsulated with an additional layer of encryption using RADIUS over Internet Protocol Security or RADIUS over Transport Layer Security.

Title: Provide frequency separation for wireless networks
Description from ISM: Wireless networks implement sufficient frequency separation from other wireless networks.

Title: Ensure WAPs enable use of 802.11w to protect management frames
Description from ISM: Wireless access points enable the use of the 802.11w amendment to protect management frames.

Title: Use more WAPs at lower broadcast power rather than few high-power WAPs
Description from ISM: Instead of deploying a small number of wireless access points that broadcast on high power, a greater number of wireless access points that use less broadcast power are deployed to achieve the desired footprint for wireless networks.

Title: Limit effective wireless range outside organisation control with RF shielding for SECRET/TOP SECRET networks
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: The effective range of wireless communications outside an organisation’s area of control is limited by implementing RF shielding on facilities in which SECRET or TOP SECRET wireless networks are used.

Title: Use cloud service providers for hosting online services
Description from ISM: Cloud service providers are used for hosting online services.

Title: Verify cloud provider scalability for capacity planning
Description from ISM: Cloud service providers’ ability to dynamically scale resources in response to a genuine spike in demand is discussed and verified as part of capacity and availability planning for online services.

Title: Architect high-availability services to transition between availability zones
Description from ISM: Where a high availability requirement exists for online services, the services are architected to automatically transition between availability zones.

Title: Continuously monitor capacity & availability of online services
Description from ISM: Continuous real-time monitoring of the capacity and availability of online services is performed.

Title: Use CDNs for high-availability website hosting
Description from ISM: Where a high availability requirement exists for website hosting, CDNs that cache websites are used.

Title: Avoid exposing origin server IP addresses when using CDNs and restrict access
Description from ISM: If using CDNs, disclosing the IP addresses of web servers under an organisation’s control (referred to as origin servers) is avoided and access to the origin servers is restricted to the CDNs and authorised management networks.

Title: Discuss DDoS mitigation with cloud providers and document thresholds/actions
Description from ISM:
Denial-of-service attack mitigation strategies are discussed with cloud service providers, specifically:
• their capacity to withstand denial-of-service attacks
• costs likely to be incurred as a result of denial-of-service attacks
• availability monitoring and thresholds for notification of denial-of-service attacks
• thresholds for turning off any online services or functionality during denial-of-service attacks
• pre-approved actions that can be undertaken during denial-of-service attacks
• any arrangements with upstream service providers to block malicious network traffic as far upstream as possible.

Title: Segregate critical online services from others likely to be targeted for DDoS
Description from ISM: Critical online services are segregated from other online services that are more likely to be targeted as part of denial-of-service attacks.

Title: Protect domain names with registrar locking and correct registration details
Description from ISM: Domain names for online services are protected via registrar locking and confirming that domain registration details are correct.

Title: Comply with ASD HACE communications security doctrine and policy
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: Communications security doctrine and policy produced by ASD for the management and operation of HACE is complied with.

Title: Obtain ASD Approval for HACE use and follow instructions
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: HACE are issued an Approval for Use by ASD and operated in accordance with the latest version of their associated Australian Communications Security Instructions.

Title: Cryptographic key management processes and procedures maintained
Description from ISM: Cryptographic key management processes, and supporting cryptographic key management procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Use ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithms for media encryption
Description from ISM: An ASD-Approved Cryptographic Algorithm (AACA) or high assurance cryptographic algorithm is used when encrypting media.

Title: Use full/partial disk encryption or partitioning for data at rest
Description from ISM: Full disk encryption, or partial encryption where access controls will only allow writing to the encrypted partition, is implemented when encrypting data at rest.

Title: Use ASD-Approved Cryptographic Protocols for data in transit
Description from ISM: An ASD-Approved Cryptographic Protocol (AACP) or high assurance cryptographic protocol is used to protect data when communicated over network infrastructure.

Title: Use Common-Criteria-evaluated cryptographic equipment/libraries for OFFICIAL/PROTECTED media
Description from ISM: Cryptographic equipment, applications or libraries that have completed a Common Criteria evaluation against an ASD-endorsed Protection Profile are used when encrypting media that contains OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data.

Title: Use HACE for SECRET/TOP SECRET media encryption
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: HACE is used when encrypting media that contains SECRET or TOP SECRET data.

Title: Use Common-Criteria-evaluated cryptographic tools for OFFICIAL/PROTECTED over insecure channels
Description from ISM: Cryptographic equipment, applications or libraries that have completed a Common Criteria evaluation against an ASD-endorsed Protection Profile are used to protect OFFICIAL: Sensitive or PROTECTED data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

Title: Use HACE for SECRET/TOP SECRET over insecure channels
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: HACE is used to protect SECRET and TOP SECRET data when communicated over insufficiently secure networks, outside of appropriately secure areas or via public network infrastructure.

Title: Encryption tools provide data recovery methods where practical
Description from ISM: Where practical, cryptographic equipment, applications and libraries provide a means of data recovery to allow for circumstances where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure.

Title: Treat user-authenticated encryption as original classification/sensitivity until deauthenticating
Description from ISM: When a user authenticates to the encryption functionality of IT equipment or media, it is treated in accordance with its original sensitivity or classification until the user deauthenticates from the encryption functionality.

Title: Transport keyed cryptographic equipment per keying sensitivity
Description from ISM: Keyed cryptographic equipment is transported based on the sensitivity or classification of its keying material.

Title: Report compromise of cryptographic equipment/keying to CISO promptly
Description from ISM: The compromise or suspected compromise of cryptographic equipment or associated keying material is reported to the chief information security officer, or one of their delegates, as soon as possible after it occurs.

Title: Change keying material when compromise is suspected/detected
Description from ISM: Keying material is changed when compromised or suspected of being compromised.

Title: Only use AACAs/high-assurance algorithms for cryptography
Description from ISM: Only AACAs or high assurance cryptographic algorithms are used by cryptographic equipment, applications and libraries.

Title: Prefer ECDH over DH
Description from ISM: ECDH is used in preference to DH.

Title: Use DH modulus >=2048 bits (prefer 3072)
Description from ISM: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

Title: Use DH modulus >=3072 bits for SECRET/TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus of at least 3072 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

Title: Select DH parameters per NIST SP 800-56A Rev.3
Description from ISM: When using DH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a modulus and associated parameters are selected according to NIST SP 800-56A Rev. 3.

Title: Use suitable curves from NIST SP 800-186 for ECC
Description from ISM: When using elliptic curve cryptography, a suitable curve from NIST SP 800-186 is used.

Title: Use ECDH base/keysize >=224 bits, prefer P-384 curve
Description from ISM: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

Title: Use NIST P-256/P-384/P-521 for ECDH (prefer P-384 curve) for SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, NIST P-256, P-384 or P-521 curves are used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

Title: Use NIST P-384/P-521 for ECDH (prefer P-384 curve) for TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to TOP SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using ECDH for agreeing on encryption session keys, NIST P-384 or P-521 curves are used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

Title: Use ECDSA base/keysize >=224 bits, prefer P-384 curve
Description from ISM: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, a base point order and key size of at least 224 bits is used, preferably the P-384 curve.

Title: Use NIST P-256/P-384/P-521 for ECDSA (prefer P-384 curve) for SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, NIST P-256, P-384 or P-521 curves are used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

Title: Use P-384/P-521 for ECDSA (prefer P-384 curve) for TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to TOP SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using ECDSA for digital signatures, NIST P-384 or P-521 curves are used, preferably the NIST P-384 curve.

Title: Follow FIPS 204 & 203 guidance when using ML-DSA/ML-KEM
Description from ISM: When using ML-DSA and ML-KEM, as per FIPS 204 and FIPS 203 respectively, adherence to pre-requisite FIPS publications is preferred.

Title: Use ML-DSA-65/87 for ML-DSA, prefer 87
Description from ISM: When using ML-DSA for digital signatures, ML-DSA-65 or ML-DSA-87 is used, preferably ML-DSA-87.

Title: Use hedged variant of ML-DSA when possible
Description from ISM: When using ML-DSA for digital signatures, the hedged variant is used whenever possible.

Title: Use pre-hashed variants of ML-DSA-65/87 only if necessary
Description from ISM: Pre-hashed variants of ML-DSA-65 and ML-DSA-87 are only used when the performance of default variants is unacceptable.

Title: Use at least SHA-384/SHA-512 for pre-hashed ML-DSA-65/87 variants
Description from ISM: When the pre-hashed variants of ML-DSA-65 and ML-DSA-87 are used, at least SHA-384 and SHA-512 respectively are used for pre-hashing.

Title: Use ML-KEM-768/1024 for key encapsulation, prefer 1024
Description from ISM: When using ML-KEM for encapsulating encryption session keys (and similar keys), ML-KEM-768 or ML-KEM-1024 is used, preferably ML-KEM-1024.

Title: Use RSA modulus >=2048 (prefer 3072)
Description from ISM: When using RSA for digital signatures, and transporting encryption session keys (and similar keys), a modulus of at least 2048 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

Title: Use RSA modulus >=3072 (prefer 3072) for SECRET/TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: When using RSA for digital signatures, and transporting encryption session keys (and similar keys), a modulus of at least 3072 bits is used, preferably 3072 bits.

Title: Use separate RSA key pairs for signatures and key transport
Description from ISM: When using RSA for digital signatures, and for transporting encryption session keys (and similar keys), a different key pair is used for digital signatures and transporting encryption session keys.

Title: Use SHA-2 with output >=224 bits, prefer SHA-384/512
Description from ISM: When using SHA-2 for hashing, an output size of at least 224 bits is used, preferably SHA-384 or SHA-512.

Title: Use SHA-2 output >=256 bits (prefer SHA-384/512) for SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using SHA-2 for hashing, an output size of at least 256 bits is used, preferably SHA-384 or SHA-512.

Title: Use SHA-2 output >=384 bits (prefer SHA-384/512) for TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to TOP SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using SHA-2 for hashing, an output size of at least 384 bits is used, preferably SHA-384 or SHA-512.

Title: Use AES for encryption, preferably AES-256
Description from ISM: When using AES for encryption, AES-128, AES-192 or AES-256 is used, preferably AES-256.

Title: Use AES-192/256 for encryption (prefer AES-256) for TOP SECRET
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to TOP SECRET classification
Description from ISM: When using AES for encryption, AES-192 or AES-256 is used, preferably AES-256.

Title: Do not use ECB mode for symmetric algorithms
Description from ISM: Symmetric cryptographic algorithms are not used in Electronic Codebook Mode.

Title: Maintain post-quantum cryptography transition plan
Description from ISM: A post-quantum cryptography transition plan is developed, implemented and maintained.

Title: Cryptographic equipment/apps/libraries support ML-DSA-87/ML-KEM-1024/SHA-384/SHA-512/AES-256 by 2030
Description from ISM: The development and procurement of new cryptographic equipment, applications and libraries ensures support for the use of ML-DSA-87, ML-KEM-1024, SHA-384, SHA-512 and AES-256 by no later than 2030.

Title: Use AACAs for post-quantum transition hybrid schemes
Description from ISM: When a post-quantum traditional hybrid scheme is used, either the post-quantum cryptographic algorithm, the traditional cryptographic algorithm or both are AACAs.

Title: Use only AACPs/high-assurance cryptographic protocols
Description from ISM: Only AACPs or high assurance cryptographic protocols are used by cryptographic equipment, applications and libraries.

Title: Use latest TLS version
Description from ISM: Only the latest version of TLS is used for TLS connections.

Title: Use AES-GCM for TLS connection encryption
Description from ISM: AES-GCM is used for encryption of TLS connections.

Title: Only allow server-initiated secure renegotiation for TLS connections
Description from ISM: Only server-initiated secure renegotiation is used for TLS connections.

Title: Use DH/ECDH for TLS key establishment
Description from ISM: DH or ECDH is used for key establishment of TLS connections.

Title: Use ephemeral DH/ECDH for TLS key establishment
Description from ISM: When using DH or ECDH for key establishment of TLS connections, the ephemeral variant is used.

Title: Do not use anonymous DH for TLS connections
Description from ISM: Anonymous DH is not used for TLS connections.

Title: Use SHA-2-based certificates for TLS connections
Description from ISM: SHA-2-based certificates are used for TLS connections.

Title: Use SHA-2 for HMAC/PRF for TLS connections
Description from ISM: SHA-2 is used for the Hash-based Message Authentication Code (HMAC) and pseudorandom function (PRF) for TLS connections.

Title: Disable TLS compression for connections
Description from ISM: TLS compression is disabled for TLS connections.

Title: Use Perfect Forward Secrecy for TLS connections
Description from ISM: Perfect Forward Secrecy (PFS) is used for TLS connections.

Title: Disable SSHv1
Description from ISM: The use of SSH version 1 is disabled for SSH connections.

Title: Configure SSH daemon with secure settings
Description from ISM:
The SSH daemon is configured to:
• only listen on the required interfaces (ListenAddress xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx)
• have a suitable login banner (Banner x)
• have a login authentication timeout of no more than 60 seconds (LoginGraceTime 60)
• disable host-based authentication (HostbasedAuthentication no)
• disable rhosts-based authentication (IgnoreRhosts yes)
• disable the ability to login directly as root (PermitRootLogin no)
• disable empty passwords (PermitEmptyPasswords no)
• disable connection forwarding (AllowTCPForwarding no)
• disable gateway ports (GatewayPorts no)
• disable X11 forwarding (X11Forwarding no).

Title: Use public key authentication for SSH
Description from ISM: Public key-based authentication is used for SSH connections.

Title: Protect SSH private keys with passphrase/key encryption
Description from ISM: SSH private keys are protected with a password or a key encryption key.

Title: When using passwordless SSH, restrict unneccessary IP addresses, port/agent credential/X11 forwarding, console access
Description from ISM:
When using logins without a password for SSH connections, the following are disabled:
• access from IP addresses that do not require access
• port forwarding
• agent credential forwarding
• X11 forwarding
• console access.

Title: Configure forced command option and parameter checking for passwordless SSH
Description from ISM: If using remote access without the use of a password for SSH connections, the ‘forced command’ option is used to specify what command is executed and parameter checking is enabled.

Title: Limit SSH-agent use to locked workstations with expiry
Description from ISM: When SSH-agent or similar key caching applications are used, it is limited to workstations and servers with screen locks and key caches that are set to expire within four hours of inactivity.

Title: Use S/MIME versions >= 3.0
Description from ISM: Versions of S/MIME earlier than S/MIME version 3.0 are not used for S/MIME connections.

Title: Use tunnel mode for IPsec (use IP tunnels if using transport mode)
Description from ISM: Tunnel mode is used for IPsec connections; however, if using transport mode, an IP tunnel is used.

Title: Use ESP for IPSec authentication/encryption
Description from ISM: The ESP protocol is used for authentication and encryption of IPsec connections.

Title: Use IKEv2 for IPsec key exchange
Description from ISM: IKE version 2 is used for key exchange when establishing IPsec connections.

Title: Use AES for IPsec encryption, prefer ENCR_AES_GCM_16
Description from ISM: AES is used for encrypting IPsec connections, preferably ENCR_AES_GCM_16.

Title: Use PRF_HMAC_SHA2_256/384/512 for IPsec, prefer PRF_HMAC_SHA2_512
Description from ISM: PRF_HMAC_SHA2_256, PRF_HMAC_SHA2_384 or PRF_HMAC_SHA2_512 is used for IPsec connections, preferably PRF_HMAC_SHA2_512.

Title: Use suitable AUTH_HMAC_SHA2 variants or NONE with AES-GCM for authenticating IPSec, prefer NONE
Description from ISM: AUTH_HMAC_SHA2_256_128, AUTH_HMAC_SHA2_384_192, AUTH_HMAC_SHA2_512_256 or NONE (only with AES-GCM) is used for authenticating IPsec connections, preferably NONE.

Title: Use DH/ECDH for IPsec key establishment with recommended DH groups
Description from ISM: DH or ECDH is used for key establishment of IPsec connections, preferably 384-bit random ECP group, 3072-bit MODP Group or 4096-bit MODP Group.

Title: Use security association lifetime of <4 hours for IPsec connections
Description from ISM: A security association lifetime of less than four hours (14400 seconds) is used for IPsec connections.

Title: Use PFS for IPsec connections
Description from ISM: PFS is used for IPsec connections.

Title: Implement gateways between different security domains
Description from ISM: Gateways are implemented between networks belonging to different security domains.

Title: Implement DMZ if external parties require access
Description from ISM: Gateways implement a demilitarised zone if external parties require access to an organisation’s services.

Title: Gateways only allow explicitly authorised data flows
Description from ISM: Gateways only allow explicitly authorised data flows.

Title: Gateways inspect/filter transport layer and above data flows
Description from ISM: Gateways inspect and filter data flows at the transport and above network layers.

Title: Gateways perform ingress traffic filtering to prevent IP spoofing
Description from ISM: Gateways perform ingress traffic filtering to detect and prevent IP source address spoofing.

Title: Gateway admins screened/cleared by sensitivity
Description from ISM: System administrators for gateways undergo appropriate employment screening, and where necessary hold an appropriate security clearance, based on the sensitivity or classification of gateways.

Title: Gateway admins for AUSTEO/RELEASABLE must be Australian nationals
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: System administrators for gateways that connect to Australian Eyes Only or Releasable To networks are Australian nationals.

Title: Gateway admins for AGAO are Australian or seconded foreign nationals
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
Description from ISM: System administrators for gateways that connect to Australian Government Access Only networks are Australian nationals or seconded foreign nationals.

Title: Gateway admins assigned least privilege
Description from ISM: System administrators for gateways are assigned the minimum privileges required to perform their duties.

Title: Separation of duties for gateway administration
Description from ISM: Separation of duties is implemented in performing administrative activities for gateways.

Title: Gateway admins formally trained on operation and management
Description from ISM: System administrators for gateways are formally trained on the operation and management of gateways.

Title: Gateways managed via an isolated secure path
Description from ISM: Gateways are managed via a secure path isolated from all connected networks.

Title: Shared gateway components managed by higher-domain admins or mutually agreed third party
Description from ISM: For gateways between networks belonging to different security domains, any shared components are managed by system administrators for the higher security domain or by system administrators from a mutually agreed upon third party.

Title: Users authenticate to networks accessed via gateways
Description from ISM: Users authenticate to other networks accessed via gateways.

Title: IT equipment authenticates to other networks via gateways
Description from ISM: IT equipment authenticates to other networks accessed via gateways.

Title: Organisation public IP addresses signed by valid ROA records
Description from ISM: Public IP addresses controlled by, or used by, an organisation are signed by valid ROA records.

Title: Reject/deprioritise invalid or overly long RPKI BGP routes
Description from ISM: Routes for RPKI-registered IP addresses that are advertised from invalid Autonomous Systems, or that are longer than allowed, are rejected or deprioritised by routers that exchange routes via BGP.

Title: Gateway events including permitted/egress flows and intrusion alerts are logged centrally
Description from ISM:
Security-relevant events for gateways are centrally logged, including:
• data packets and data flows permitted through gateways
• data packets and data flows attempting to leave gateways
• real-time alerts for attempted intrusions.

Title: Test gateways after config changes and at least every 6 months
Description from ISM: Gateways undergo testing following configuration changes, and at regular intervals no more than six months apart, to validate they conform to expected security configurations.

Title: Non-classified gateways undergo IRAP assessment at least every 24 months
Description from ISM: Non-classified, OFFICIAL: Sensitive, PROTECTED and SECRET gateways undergo an IRAP assessment, using the latest release of the ISM available prior to the beginning of the IRAP assessment (or a subsequent release), at least every 24 months.

Title: TOP SECRET gateways assessed by ASD at least every 24 months
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to TOP SECRET classification
Description from ISM: TOP SECRET gateways undergo a security assessment by ASD assessors (or their delegates), using the latest release of the ISM available prior to the beginning of the assessment (or a subsequent release), at least every 24 months.

Title: CDSs implemented between SECRET/TOP SECRET and other domains
Non Applicability Rationale: Protected classification; Control only applicable to SECRET and TOP SECRET classifications
